newsitem.title: KUWAIT: Kuwait says British missile deal on hold.
newsitem.headline: Kuwait says British missile deal on hold.

text.p: Kuwait has not finalised a missile deal with Britain and has formed a committee to investigate claims of waste of public funds, the acting prime minister was quoted on Wednesday as saying.
"No deal has been signed for this missile or that missile," Sheikh Sabah al-Ahmad al-Sabah, who is also foreign minister, told parliament, Kuwaiti newspapers reported.

Parliament placed the issue on the agenda for Tuesday after reports last month that Kuwait had intialled deals with British Aerospace Plc for Sea Skua surface-to-surface missiles despite strong objections by some MPs.

"We have formed a committee to give us a fuller picture about the issue and investigate the talk we hear about waste of public funds," said Sheikh Sabah who has been heading the government since Prime Minister and Crown Prince Sheikh Saad al- Abdulla al-Sabah fell ill last month and went to Britain.
In February, Defence Minister Sheikh Salem Sabah al-Salem al-Sabah said the decision to buy the British system was final, dropping a cheaper offer for France's Aerospatiale MM-15 missiles.

Kuwait newspapers earlier said the British offer was for around $90 million but experts said the contract was split into several deals, including training and a British gift of 20 Skua missiles, making it difficult to give an exact figure.
The missiles will arm Kuwait's eight, French-made $500 million fast patrol boats ordered in 1995.
